Equating (4) and (5) says $2y^2 = y^4$, so $y = -\sqrt{2}, 0,$ or $\sqrt{2}.$ Assume $y = \sqrt{2}.$ Letting $t = f(y^2), s = y$ says (6) $f(f(f(y^2)) + y^2) = f(3y^2)$ $ = f(y^2) + (f(y))^2$; but $s = \sqrt{2}y, t = y$ says (7) $f(3y^2) = (f(\sqrt{2}y))^2 + y = (f(y^2))^2 + y$. Since $(f(y))^2 = y^4$, $f(y^2) = y + y^2$, equating the RHS of (6) and (7) leaves $$ f(y^2) + (f(y))^2 = (f(y^2))^2 + y \implies y + y^2 + y^4 = (y^4 + 2y^3 + y^2) + y \implies 2y^3 = 0$$ which is absurd. eq - \sqrt{2}.$ We conclude that $f(0) = 0$. That $ orall x \in \mathbb{R} (f(f(x)) = x)$ says that $f(x) = f^{-1}(x);$ this requires that $f$ be one-to-one. Since $f(0) = 0$, we have $t

eq 0$; we can now show that $f$ is increasing. Pick $x, y \in \mathbb{R}, x < y,$ and set $\delta = y - x.$ By choosing $t = f(x), s = \sqrt{\delta}$, we have $$f(\delta + f(f(x))) = f(\delta + x) = f(x) + f(\sqrt{\delta})^2 \implies f(x + \delta) - f(x) = f(\sqrt{\delta})^2$$ $$	herefore f(y) - f(x) > 0$$ since we established that $f(\sqrt{\delta}) 
eq 0$. This proves that $f$ is increasing. Since, in fact, $\mathrm{Id}(x)$ is the only $f: \mathbb{R} ightarrow \mathbb{R}$ which is both increasing and an involution, this says that $f(x) = x$ is the sole function with the property ($\pi$). The required properties of the function $a$ imply that the natural numbers lie in its domain. However, the domain specified here is any arbitrary set $X$ which may not contain the natural numbers. If the domain of $a$ was restricted to the set of natural numbers, the statement of the exercise itself serves as a complete definition of the function, from which it's existence and uniqueness follow directly (I may be wrong here.
